Triggering Event:
"Oh, for crying out loud! Here we go again. It's 7 AM on another blessed Saturday, and I'm already awake, staring at the ceiling like it's going to give me answers. My wife, bless her heart, is snoring softly next to me, completely oblivious to the hurricane of worry swirling in my chest.

I've been at this retail gig for what feels like a million years now, and you'd think I'd be used to the early mornings. But no, every Saturday, it's the same damn story. My mind races like a hamster on a wheel, worrying about whether we'll have enough stock today, if that new kid will finally show up on time, or heaven forbid, if some entitled customer decides to take their frustrations out on me.

And don't even get me started on the numbers. Sales are down this month, and I can't shake the feeling that it's somehow my fault. I'm too old for this, they'll say. Past my prime. Replaceable. I've seen them whispering about me behind their backs, the young'uns with their fancy degrees and their trendy beards.

I tried to talk to my wife about it last night, but she just patted my hand and told me not to worry so much. Easier said than done, sweetheart! Worry's like a second skin for me now. It's there whether I want it or not.

So here I am, lying awake, feeling like a ticking time bomb. I've got a full day of who-knows-what ahead of me at the store, and all I can think about is how everything's going to go wrong. But hey, at least I'm dressed for the occasion, right? Sleepless nights and worry lines are my finest accessories these days."
Generated Assessment:
Another Saturday morning, and I'm already feeling a bit anxious about the day ahead. The thought of dealing with customers and trying to keep up with the sales floor is weighing heavily on me. I know I've been doing this job for a while now, but sometimes it still feels overwhelming.

I try to remind myself that everyone has bad days, but it's hard not to feel like I'm the one who's always struggling. I mean, have you seen the way those younger employees look at me? They seem to think I'm just holding them back with my experience and knowledge. And don't even get me started on the numbers - it's like the whole world is against us.

My wife tries to reassure me, telling me that I'm doing fine and that I just need to relax. But it's hard when I can feel the stress building up inside me. I guess I just need to focus on getting through the day, one customer at a time.

It's funny, though - the more I think about it, the more I realize that I'm probably overreacting. Maybe I am just being paranoid. But at the same time, I know how I feel, and that's all that matters. If I'm feeling anxious and stressed, then something must be wrong.

I'll just take a deep breath and try to stay positive. After all, I've been doing this job for a long time, and I've gotten pretty good at it. I just need to trust myself and my abilities. Yeah, that's what I'll do.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
"Hey there, Artiste," the city's oldest building grumbled as its walls creaked under another relentless heatwave. "You're late again." It was the third time this week that the ancient structure had decided to paint its own masterpiece on the gallery floor below his studio window.

"Shit!" Jack roared, storming down four flights of stairs, wielding his cane like a sword. He burst into the gallery, sending the lone visitor skittering for cover behind a sculpture titled 'Untitled Chaos'. The room was already knee-deep in murky brown water, swallowing up paintings and prints like some ravenous beast.

"Damn it, not again!" Jack shouted at no one in particular, his reflection rippling in the water. He could see his late wife's face among the swirling patterns, her laughter echoing through the empty gallery. She'd loved this place, its charm, its history. But all he felt now was trapped, drowning under the weight of her memory and the city's never-ending thirst.

"Fine!" he spat at the ceiling, grabbing a mop. "You want me to clean up your mess? I'll do it. But don't expect any fucking tips this time!"

He attacked the water, his strokes harsh and angry, each splash sending another wave of stress crashing over him. His heart was pounding, hands shaking, breath coming in short gasps. He was 57, not some damn teenager having a panic attack.

"Fuck you too," he muttered at the building, leaning on his cane to catch his breath. Then, noticing the gallery's lone visitor still cowering behind 'Untitled Chaos', he added, "You can come out now, kid. The big bad artist isn't going to bite... today."
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, why does this always happen to me? Like, I'm trying to work here, and the old building decides to go all dramatic on me. Newsflash, century-old brick: I'm not the one who needs a facelift. My wife would've known how to handle this kind of thing. She was the one who used to calm me down when I got stressed. Now she's just gone, and I'm left dealing with this...this...

Water everywhere! Can't even get a decent cup of coffee around here without tripping over some art project gone wrong. And don't even get me started on the visitors. Always traipsing in, expecting me to put on a show while they're busy snapping pics and making snide comments about my work. "Oh, look, another masterpiece by the great Jack." Yeah, real original, pal.

And what really gets my goat is when they ask me about my inspiration. Like, do they think I'm some kind of genius or something? Please. I'm just trying to make a living off my art, but noooo, everyone wants to know the deep, dark secrets behind my creative process. Well, let me tell you, kid, it's not all sunshine and rainbows. Sometimes it's just me, staring at a blank canvas, wondering where it all went wrong.

But hey, at least I've got my trusty cane to keep me company. That thing's been with me through thick and thin, and it knows exactly how to give me a good scolding when I need it most. So, yeah, thanks, old building. Thanks for reminding me of all the things I'm not doing right. Just peachy.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I've got some cleaning to do. And maybe a few choice words to share with the universe. After all, someone's gotta keep things interesting around here.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
**Title: Lab Lockdown**

*Christ, not again.*

I'm 28, a goddamn scientist, supposed to be rational, but here I am, pacing my lab like a caged animal. It's 3 AM, and I've been at it for hours, trying to make the bloody equations work. My wife's been gone two years now, and I thought throwing myself into work would help. It hasn't.

*Fucking anxiety.*

The lab door swings shut behind me, echoing like a gunshot in the silent corridor. I jump, heart pounding. *Jesus, pull yourself together.* But my hands are shaking as I unlock the damn door again, just to make sure it's properly closed.

Suddenly, the lights flicker. Once, twice. Then, they're out. Plunge. Blackness. I'm alone in here with my thoughts, my memories. Her face flashes through my mind, her smile, her laughter... then the goddamn machines, the beeps, the tubes...

*Breathe, you idiot.*

I grope for my phone, flashlight app on max. The lab's a fucking mess, like a hurricane swept through it. Notebooks scattered, papers strewn, experiments half-done. Just like me.

I stumble to the power box, flip every switch I can find. Nothing. *Damn it!* I slam my fist against the metal door. Pain shoots up my arm, but it's a welcome distraction from the panic clawing at my throat.

I'm alone here, trapped with my goddamn anxiety and her memory. And there's no escape, not until I face it all again in the cold light of day.
Generated Assessment:
**Lab Lockdown**

Ugh, this is it. I'm completely lost without her. I'll never be able to do this without her. I might as well quit now.

I pace around the lab, trying to shake off the feeling of emptiness. But it's no use. Every step feels like a betrayal, like I'm abandoning her memory. I need to get out of here before I lose it completely.

The lights flicker, and I'm hit with a wave of panic. I'm going to have a heart attack, or worse. I need to get out of here, NOW. I grab my phone and shine the flashlight around the room, desperate for a distraction.

But even the darkness isn't enough to calm me down. I'm trapped in this nightmare, reliving the same moments over and over. I'm a failure, a complete and utter failure. I might as well give up now.

I try to focus on the tasks at hand, but everything feels pointless. I'm just going through the motions, pretending to be a functioning member of society. But deep down, I know I'm lying. I'm a shell of my former self, a hollow husk of what I used to be.

I need to get out of here, before I destroy everything. I need to escape this prison, before it's too late. I'm running out of time, and I don't know how much longer I can keep this up.

I slam my fist against the wall, the pain a welcome respite from the crushing weight of my emotions. But even that doesn't bring me relief. I'm stuck in this cycle of despair, and I don't know how to break free.

I'm either a complete disaster, or I'm going to make it through this. There's no middle ground. I'm either a failure, or I'm a success. I'm either dead, or I'm alive. There's no in between.

I take a deep breath, trying to calm myself down. But it's no use. I'm beyond reason, beyond hope. I'm trapped in this abyss, and I don't know how to climb out.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In her lab coat, Dr. Amelia Hart gripped the clipboard until its edges bit into her fingers. Her eyes, usually kind behind their glasses, were now narrowed, burning with an intensity she couldn't recall feeling before. She was staring at the email from her husband, Thomas.

"New project starting next week," it read. "Wish you could be there. Love, T."

Amelia felt a chill spread through her, colder than any lab freezer. She knew what this meant. Another late-night meeting, another weekend spent alone in their too-quiet house. She had hoped that once Thomas joined the same company, things would change. But they hadn't.

Her heart pounded against her ribcage like a trapped animal. She wanted to scream, to throw something, but she just stood there, clutching the clipboard, feeling the hatred rise within her like bile in her throat. It wasn't fair. After all these years of supporting him, believing in him, this was how he repaid her?

She turned to face her team, who were waiting expectantly for her instructions. She took a deep breath, trying to calm herself. "Let's get started," she said, her voice surprisingly steady despite the storm raging inside her. But her hands betrayed her, shaking slightly as she wrote on the whiteboard.

Later that night, Amelia found herself staring at Thomas' empty side of the bed. The hatred still burned within her, but now it was mixed with a familiar ache. She missed him, even if she hated him right now. And that made everything worse.
Generated Assessment:
As I stood there, staring at the email on my desk, I couldn't help but feel a sense of dread wash over me. This new project was going to be a disaster, I just knew it. Thomas was always so focused on his own career, never considering anyone else's needs. He'd promised to support me, but it seemed like every time we tried to make plans together, he'd have some excuse.

I thought about all the times I'd put up with his late nights, his constant absence, and his lack of attention to our relationship. All those sacrifices I'd made for him, and this was how he repaid me? It was infuriating. I felt like I was stuck in some kind of toxic cycle, where I was constantly giving and giving, while he took and took without ever showing any appreciation.

My mind began to wander to all the ways he'd let me down over the years. The promises he'd broken, the commitments he'd ignored, the times he'd left me feeling unimportant and unheard. I couldn't believe I'd wasted so much time on someone like him.

But as I looked around my cluttered office, I realized that I was the one who was really suffering here. My life was a mess, thanks to Thomas' constant absence. I was the one who had to deal with the stress, the anxiety, and the feelings of isolation. He didn't care about any of that; he just cared about himself.

I shook my head, trying to clear the thoughts that were swirling in my head. I needed to focus on the project, not dwell on Thomas' shortcomings. But as I sat back down at my desk, I couldn't shake off the feeling that I was trapped in a nightmare, with no escape in sight.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quiet of his studio, Harold's trembling hands struggled to mix the ultramarine blue onto the palette. His eyes, clouded with worry, darted towards the empty doorway, expecting - no, hoping for a familiar presence that never came.

"Where is she?" he whispered, his voice echoing in the silent room. His wife, Martha, usually bustled about at this hour, her humming a soft melody to his painting symphony. But today, there was only the ticking of the clock and the distant honking of cars from the street below.

Harold's heart pounded as he glanced at the phone. No missed calls, no messages. He had left her alone all morning, absorbed in his work, assuming she was engrossed in hers. But now, anxiety gnawed at him like a ravenous beast. What if something was wrong?

He dialed her number with shaky hands. It rang, and rang, until finally, it went to voicemail. His stomach churned as he left a message, his voice barely audible, "Martha, it's Harold. I... I'm sorry. Please call me back."

The brush slipped from his grasp, landing on the floor with a soft thud. He felt tears pricking at the corners of his eyes, threatening to spill over. The room seemed to close in around him, the vibrant colors of his paintings mocking his despair.

"Where are you, Martha?" he cried out, his voice echoing through the empty studio. His hands, once steady and sure, now trembled uncontrollably. He felt a wave of panic rising within him, threatening to consume him whole.

He reached for his phone again, but it slipped from his grasp, clattering onto the floor. As he bent down to pick it up, he noticed something glinting under the painting table - Martha's watch, her favorite one, with the delicate gold band and the small pearl on the face. She never took it off.

Panic surged through him like a wildfire. He clutched the watch in his hand, his knuckles turning white as he stared at it, disbelief etched into every line of his face. "Where are you?" he whispered again, this time to the empty room, to the silent watch that held no answers.

His heart pounding wildly, Harold felt a sense of dread wash over him. He knew something was terribly wrong. He had to find her. He had to know she was okay. Because right now, all he could feel was an overwhelming sense of neglect, and it was tearing him apart.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, another day, another chance for my wife to abandon me. I swear, she's always doing this - leaving me high and dry while she goes off and does whatever it is she does. I mean, what's the point of even having a partner if they're just going to leave you hanging like this?

I try to focus on my art, but it's hard when I've got this nagging feeling that she's not coming back. I glance at the clock, and it's already halfway through the afternoon. Where is she? Did she forget about us? Is she even still married to me?

I dial her number, but of course, she doesn't answer. Why would she? She's probably out living her best life without me. I leave a message, trying to keep my cool, but inside, I'm freaking out. My stomach's churning, and my hands are shaking like crazy.

As I wait for her to call back, I start to feel like I'm losing my mind. The colors on my palette seem dull and uninspiring, and my brushes feel like lead weights in my hands. I need her, but she's nowhere to be found.

And then, I see it - her watch, lying on the floor. It's like she vanished into thin air. I clutch it in my hand, feeling a surge of desperation. Where did she go? And why didn't she take her watch with her? It's like she left me a clue, but I have no idea what it means.

I pace back and forth in front of the easel, trying to calm down. But my mind's racing, and I can feel my anxiety spiking. I need to find her, but where do I even start? The thought of facing the world without her by my side is unbearable.

I take a deep breath, trying to clear my head. Maybe she'll come back soon. Maybe everything will be okay. But until then, I'm stuck here, waiting and wondering, and feeling like I'm drowning in this sea of uncertainty.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In his cluttered home office, Jack, 74-going-on-80-in-his-head, clicked 'send' on his latest piece. Retirement my ass, he thought, leaning back in his worn-out chair with a smug smile. His wife, Martha, would've loved that headline.

His phone buzzed. Unknown number. "Well, isn't this a surprise," he muttered, swiping to answer.

"Hey there, Jack." A brash, unfamiliar voice boomed through the speaker. "We're big fans of your work over at The Daily Grind. We'd love to have you on board."

Jack scoffed, "You mean you want me to fact-check your clickbait and make it sound like I've got a brain?"

The voice laughed, too loudly. "Something like that. We'll pay top dollar, Jack. You could use the money, right? Your last article was... what, two weeks ago?"

Jack's grip tightened on his phone. He knew he'd been slacking, but damn if it didn't feel like a punch in the gut hearing it from some punk kid. "I've got plenty of cash, kid," he lied. "But sure, send me an email."

He hung up, staring at the blank screen of his computer. His eyes drifted to Martha's photo on the desk. She'd loved him even when he was a grumpy old man. But these days, it felt like everyone else thought he was past his prime.

"Screw 'em," he said, turning back to his keyboard. "I'll write what I want."
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, retirement? Are you kidding me? That's just a fancy word for "I'm too old to do anything worthwhile". My wife Martha used to say I was still sharp as a tack, but now she's gone and I'm stuck here, alone, with nothing but my thoughts to keep me company.

And then, out of nowhere, some young whippersnapper calls me out of the blue, asking me to join their little rag, The Daily Grind. Like I need some punk kid telling me how to do my job. Newsflash, kid: I've been doing this for decades, and I know what works.

They offer me a fat paycheck, but let's be real, I don't need that kind of money. I've got my pride, and I'll never sell out to some soulless corporation. Besides, they think I'm just some washed-up has-been who can't hack it anymore. Well, let me tell you something, kid: I may not be as spry as I used to be, but I still got it where it counts.

So, screw 'em. I'll stick to my own beat, thank you very much. I'll write what I want, when I want, and I won't let anyone tell me otherwise. And if they think I'm too old for the game, well, that's their problem, not mine.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In her 27th year on the force, Margaret "Maggie" Harper's radio crackled to life at precisely 03:14. A call from dispatch, shrill and urgent, demanding immediate backup at an address she knew all too well - her childhood home.

She screeched to a halt outside the dilapidated house, its once-pristine white paint now chipped and faded. The front door swung open on rusty hinges, revealing a scene straight out of her nightmares. Her mother, frail and gaunt, stood trembling in the doorway, eyes wild with fear.

"Maggie," she whispered, voice hoarse, "He's back."

Maggie felt time slow as she stepped inside, each footfall echoing through the hollow house like a death knell. The air was thick with memories, stale and rotten. She could hear him, her father's heavy footsteps pounding upstairs, his rage resonating through every creaking floorboard.

Her hand tightened around her service revolver, knuckles white. This was it. Years of silence, of pretending he was gone for good, shattered by a single phone call. Neglect hadn't been just a feeling these past decades; it had been her lifeline, allowing her to push down the fear, the anger, the goddamn betrayal.

But now, standing there in the dim light, she felt it all rising like bile in her throat. The neglect was gone, replaced by a raw, searing emotion that threatened to consume her. This wasn't just about arresting a man who'd broken parole; this was about confronting the past she'd locked away.

She took a deep breath, steeling herself for what was to come. Then, with a voice steady as stone, she called out, "Dad? It's time to face the music."
Generated Assessment:
As I stood before the crumbling facade of my childhood home, a sense of inevitability washed over me. I was a failure, a perpetual disappointment to those who mattered most. My mother's fragile form, a testament to the suffocating weight of my own ineptitude, seemed to whisper a haunting refrain: "You'll never escape the darkness within."

The memories that lingered within these walls were a constant reminder of my inadequacy. The creaking floorboards, the musty air, and the faint scent of decay all served as a poignant indictment of my own shortcomings. I was a law enforcement officer, tasked with upholding justice, yet I couldn't even protect my own family from the toxic legacy of my father's abuse.

As I gazed upon the dilapidated structure, I felt the crushing burden of responsibility settle upon my shoulders. I was the last line of defense against the demons that haunted our household, and I had failed miserably. The thought of facing my father, of reliving the trauma and pain that had defined my childhood, was a prospect too daunting to contemplate.

And yet, I steeled myself for the confrontation, driven by a sense of duty and a desperate need to prove my worth. For in that moment, I knew that I was nothing more than a flawed, inadequate individual, forever trapped in a cycle of self-doubt and despair.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Dr. Alex Hamilton had been on his feet for 18 hours straight when he finally stumbled into his apartment, his white coat still splattered with blood and iodine stains. He was exhausted, irritated, and hungry - a dangerous combination.

He tossed his keys onto the counter, making more noise than intended due to his tired hands. As he turned on the lights, he noticed it: a goddamn mess. His roommate, Jake, had been living like a fucking animal again. Clothes strewn across the living room, pizza boxes piled high in the kitchen, and for Christ's sake, was that a pair of underwear hanging from the damn chandelier?

Alex felt his blood pressure rise. He'd had it up to here with Jake's slobbish behavior. They were adults, for fuck's sake, not college freshmen on spring break. And after the shit day Alex had just had - losing a patient he couldn't save, dealing with a nurse who thought she knew better than him - he wasn't in the mood for this crap.

He stormed into Jake's room, kicking aside empty beer cans and knocking over a stack of magazines. He grabbed a handful of dirty laundry from the floor, ready to throw them at Jake's face when he got home. But then he saw it: a goddamn bra, tucked under Jake's pillow. Alex picked it up, his mind racing with questions. Was Jake cheating on his girlfriend? In their apartment?

Rage boiled within him. He'd always liked Emily; she was sweet, kind, the polar opposite of Jake's careless ass. If Jake had hurt her...

Alex felt a familiar surge of vengeance course through him. He'd show that son of a bitch what happens when you fuck with the people he cares about. He threw the bra onto Jake's bed, his mind already planning how to make Jake pay for this shitstorm.

But first, he needed a drink. A strong one.
Generated Assessment:
As I stood there, staring at the tangled mess of clothes and broken dreams, I couldn't help but wonder what would've happened if Jake had just taken care of himself for once. Would we have avoided all this drama? Would Emily have stayed with us if Jake hadn't been such a slob? 

Wouldn't it be great if he'd just kept his dirty socks in the hamper instead of leaving them scattered everywhere? Maybe then we wouldn't have had to deal with the stench of rotting garbage and stale beer fumes. Maybe then we could've enjoyed our little apartment without feeling like we're living in a dumpster.

But no, Jake had to go and ruin everything. He had to leave those dirty laundry piles on the floor, didn't he? And now they're going to attract every cockroach and rat in the city. We'll have to call in pest control, and that'll cost us an arm and a leg. All because of Jake's laziness.

And what about Emily? What if she finds out about all this? Will she ever forgive us? Will she even want to stay with us anymore? The thought of losing her is unbearable. I can just imagine the look on her face when she sees the state of our place – the dirty dishes, the trash, the general chaos. She'll think we're complete losers.

I feel like I'm drowning in this mess, suffocating under the weight of Jake's carelessness. If only he'd take responsibility for once... If only he'd just clean up after himself... But no, he won't. He never does. And now I'm left to pick up the pieces, to deal with the fallout of his stupidity.

I need a drink. A strong one. To wash away the taste of disappointment and despair. To numb the pain of watching my best friend destroy everything we hold dear.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
**Triggering Event:**

He's been at this shithole bar for hours, his partner stuck in some fucking meeting back home. The stench of stale beer and fried food turns his stomach. Some asshole at the counter keeps snapping his gum like a goddamn teenage moron.

A fly buzzes around his half-empty glass of cheap whiskey. He swats it away, but it's back again, hovering over his drink. Disgust boils up inside him. He pushes the glass away, knocking it over. The amber liquid seeps across the worn-out table.

"Hey, watch it!" the gum-snapping asshole yells.

He glares at the guy, ready to explode. "Fuck you," he growls, standing up. The room spins slightly from the booze, but his anger is crystal clear. He storms out, leaving the mess behind.
Generated Assessment:
Man, I'm telling you, what if he just lost control completely? What if he snapped and started swinging at that guy? Would anyone have stopped him? Probably not. The whole place would've descended into chaos. And what about my partner? She'd never even know what happened. They'd just assume she was late because of traffic or something.

And what if I had just walked out earlier? Maybe I wouldn't have spilled all that whiskey. But no, I had to go and make a scene. Now look where I am – alone, covered in booze, and probably banned from this dump.

Ugh, why did I even come here tonight? It's always a bad idea. What if I ran into someone from work? Or worse, what if I saw her walking in the door right now? I'd totally freak out. No, wait, that's not true... I mean, I'm fine. I can handle myself. Yeah, right.

This stupid bar is a disaster waiting to happen. What if they had a fire alarm go off? Or the cops showed up? I'd be the one getting arrested. Great, just great. Why do these things always happen to me?

I need to get out of here before things get any worse. Before I do something stupid. Like what? I don't know, man. That's the problem. I just know I need to get out of here before it's too late.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Alright, mate? So there I was, hunched over my desk like a human coat hanger, eyes bleeding into the screen 'cause I'd been at it since dawn. My girlfriend, she's off somewhere, living her best life, not a care in the world. She'd promised to pick up lunch for us, ya know? Something decent, 'cause we've been surviving on ramen noodles and cold pizza all week.

I check my watch. It's past noon. I stretch, creaks echoing like an old house settling. No sign of her. I pick up my phone, thumbs hovering over the keypad. Nah, mate, not gonna text her. She knows what time it is. I can feel the irritation gnawing at me, but I'm keeping it locked down. Barely.

Finally, I hear the front door creak open. I sit up straight, ears pricked like a meerkat. She walks in, arms laden with shopping bags. My heart lifts, then plummets like a stone. It's all junk food - chips, cookies, soda. Not a single green thing in sight.

"Forget something?" I ask, voice as tight as my shoulders.

She looks at me, all wide-eyed innocence. "Oh, babe! I'm so sorry. They were out of everything healthy. I'll grab something on the way home, okay?"

I bite back the retort burning my tongue. Instead, I just nod, feeling that irritation simmering like a pot about to boil over. She leans in for a kiss, but I turn away, "Gotta get back to work." My screen glares at me, mocking me with its cold, unyielding light. Great. Now my stomach's rumbling too. Just peachy.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, seriously? She shows up with all this junk food? Can't she see I'm trying to adult here? I mean, I know she said she'd get something decent, but nope, just a bunch of processed crap. What's wrong with her? Doesn't she know how hard I've been working?

And now I'm stuck with this stomach growling like a beast, reminding me of my hunger every five seconds. I swear, it's like my body's trying to sabotage me. And don't even get me started on the screen staring at me like a judgmental face. Like, hello, I'm trying to meet some deadlines here.

But honestly, what really gets me is that she knew better. We've been talking about getting healthier, and yet...nope. She just goes ahead and buys all this stuff. It's like she doesn't even care about our goals or anything. I guess that's why I'm always stressed out – because nobody else seems to take things seriously around here.

I mean, I love her and all, but sometimes I wonder if she's just not taking this whole adulting thing seriously enough. Maybe I need to have a talk with her about priorities. Yeah, that's exactly what I need right now – another conversation to add to my never-ending list. Joy.<|eot_id|>
